It's great that you're aware of Billy's behavior and are taking steps to ensure everyone gets their fair share of food. Separating him during feeding time is a good idea, and you might also consider using feeding barriers or individual feeding stations to prevent competition and stress.

It's not uncommon for goats to be a bit food-aggressive, especially if they're not getting enough to eat or if they're feeling competitive. By providing a safe and stress-free feeding environment, you can help reduce conflicts and ensure everyone stays healthy and happy.

Remember to also monitor the body condition and weight of all your animals, including Billy, to make sure they're getting the right amount of nutrients and not overeating or under-eating. Your veterinarian or equine nutritionist can help you with this.

By the way, have you considered providing enrichment activities or toys for your goats to keep them occupied and stimulated? Goats are intelligent and curious creatures, and they can get bored or restless if they don't have enough to do. Providing things like puzzle feeders, climbing structures, or even just a few old tires to play with can help keep them happy and engaged.
